From my (limited) experience, it is not that no one can mount any credible counter-arguments, it is that Chomsky fails to treat any counter-arguments as credible.

By just about any definition of credibility, it is obvious that much of the world, even much of the rarefied realm of genius academic/public intellectual social scientist, disagrees with much of what Chomsky says.

Perhaps his self-satisfied dismissiveness hurts.And engenders hostility that would prevent the discovery of areas of mutual agreement.

See the current Republican Congressional delegation for further examples of this phenomenon.

" B12 is affected, and what else?"

Calcium! Osteoporosis is a major risk associated with long-term PPI use. And if you look at the product inserts, you'll see that the effect of the 20 mg dose is nearly the same as the 40 mg dose, so at the very least you should look into switching to the lighter dose.

I was taking Nexium for years, and stopped after reading about the risk of Osteoporosis. My symptoms have been negligible. There are way too many people taking these drugs for way too long!

I have been taking a PPI (omeprazole 40 mg.) and a H2RA (ranitidine 150 mg.) daily for three years, since my treatment for throat cancer. My ENT feels any reflux, which I'm more at risk for now, could be especially damaging to the treated area.

I have wondered how a lowered-acid environment in my stomach might affect nutrition. B12 is affected, and what else? Another question for my dietitian.

My heart aches for Dasani. I am very touched by her story. Getting to adulthood on track will be a challenge. I was homeless at different times as a child. The pain and the shame of it lingers for a lifetime. It is not impossible to escape this though; however, my mother did not have drug problems or the role model conflicts that I see here. I will pray for her and her family.

The constant conflict and fights that she has are going to eventually overcome her if someone doesn't intervene or stop the cycle of learned behavior from mother to daughter. This is not uncommon for the oldest child in such circumstances(fighting). My older sister was very protective of us, almost to a fault. Unfortunately, it sounds like she is doing too much of the parenting and responsibilities at home.

I suggest that her parents pick up and move to a completely different state with one months income (if that is all they have) and start a different life. Take all 8 (?) kids, move to a smaller city and don't look back. It won't be the School of Arts that gets Dasani out of this mess, but a secure home, even if it isn't much. A 3-4 bedroom apartment would probably work with their income and there are plenty of cities with affordable rates. Any type of private situation would be better than the shame, stigma and helplessness brought to these children from living in these conditions. Get out of that town. It is going to kill you and those kids!

This is an article that reminds me of darker times in my own life, however I feel for the little black kids who probably didn't get out of the ghetto of my youth.  The only part of that life that is still with me is the shame and insecurity that comes with experiencing so much despair at such a young age.  May God bless us all to live proudly no matter what our circumstances are.  To be "Giants" as the article so eloquently described it no matter what our social stature may be.  It will be these castaways, these nameless nuisances to the gentry, that will inherit the Kingdom of the Lord.

I suggest that readers of this article living in the NYC-area take the opportunity to visit the Auburn shelter themselves and spend some time volunteering there. Why not, as PJU suggests, "reach out to help" the kids stuck living at Auburn? Dasani and her family may have moved on, but there are plenty of needy kids still there. The group New York Cares runs several reading programs for children in the rec room of the center -- and is always seeking new volunteers and ideas for other volunteer programs. See newyorkcares.org for more information.

The article is quite clear that Chanel and Supreme have received just exactly that kind of help -- but keep wasting their money and misallocating it anyways. They are described as being angry and insulted when social workers "criticize them".

The author avoids saying where Supreme, who controls all the family's welfare benefits, actually spends several thousand dollars a month. It cannot be on food. At one point she says "the SNAP money is all gone after ONE WEEK...." -- that's almost $1300 gone in a week? what were they eating, foie gras?

One other thing--  I think that mental illness plays a part in this cycle of homelessness.  Also many poor people have very poor financial plans.  Finances are something that you have to learn.  If you don't, you will be inept at it, just like any other chore.  People think that cleaning house and cooking are the only things that are important for maintaining  a house.  It is very important to learn to live within your means.  I understand that sometime that is nothing; however, this family does have an income. They need some help planning!
Jan....I think more appropriately  it's 'regardless of society's failings'

I've always thought one such philosophical mistake was Rand's not noticing, or in the alternative noticing but not minding, that "A is A" is what we like to call 'a tautology'.

Rand's entire oeuvre is just chock full of overwrought personal emotional needs masquerading as much, much higher virtues (monetary theory being just one) and the masquerades are just way too flimsy to hold up under any scrutiny at all. This is why Rand is a phase almost everyone goes through as a young adult, but then leaves behind... and with an icky feeling to boot. As philosophy, as wisdom, as guidance -- it just falls flatter and flatter the more experience of real life one gains. I've come to see still loving Rand as an adult as a surefire sign of arrested emotional development.

Returning to the topic at hand, the resonance of the money monologue to which PK refers is IMHO mainly about some readers' deep emotional need to see money as being what that character says it is. The problem is that in reality, that isn't at all what money is. Money's characteristics are Objectively (heh heh) just about completely different from what he waxes so passionately and eloquently about. Unfortunately Randians as a group are too in thrall to their emotions concerning money to adapt to what money really is, and given the positions some of them occupy that's a problem.

They keep using that word Money. I do not think that word means what they think it means.

Rand is a "red herring." The "philosophy behind these differences in their view of life" that we should be concerned about can be found in this document published before Rand was born: http://dwardmac.pitzer.edu/Anarchist_Archives/bakunin/stateless.html

-"The two personalities are incompatible. "

It has little to do with "personalities," the incompatibility that should concern us that of anarchism and democracy. It truly is one or the other.

-" if we follow her reductions to their 'logical conclusions'" we will lose our democratic republic as Franklin warned:

http://www.ted.com/talks/lawrence_lessig_we_the_people_and_the_republic_...

What seems to be overlooked in all these arguments, is the philosophy behind these differences in their view of life.

One poster mentioned Ayn Rand as the motivator of Paul Ryan's views. However he is typical of a Rand follower, picking and choosing what they like, and ignoring the rest.

Rand also wrote about self esteem, and how it is achieved, and about what she called "Sense of Life." there are those who view the world as malevolent, and believe they have to protect themselves from it, and those who think the world about them is a great place to be. The two personalities are incompatible. The also wrote about the need to be perfectly honest with yourself, and not to rationalize.

Now most off you will disagree with her philosophy, and it does lead to some pretty drastic ends, but that does not invalidate her insight into the psychology of the individual. She made strict logic the basis of her philosophy, and that appeals to many, who like to think of themselves as being completely rational. However we see from their actions, they are not, and if we follow her reductions to their "logical conclusions" we can find several errors."

But people like Ryan and Paul are true believers and are unable to examine their own behavior and beliefs. These conservatives hold moral views going back to the Puritans, dividing the citizenry into good and bad people, and they do not like reality, to them the world is malevolent.

Social Security trust funds are raided to make the rest of the budget look good. Guess where a lot of government borrowing for other programs occurs. SocSec has to buy Teasuries to invest, hence it is lending money to the rest of the government, not contributing to the deficit.

Same old problems.  Spending for the discretionary rest of government other than homeland security is less than 20% of the budget and dropping every year while defense, homeland security, social security, medicare, other mandatory spending and the debt service take up the rest and are responsible for much of the debt.  This has been happening for over a decade now and longer than the past two years described in the article.   At least he recognized the 8+% cut in just the last two years.  It comes down to priorities and arguing about 18% of the budget and ignoring the other 82% is fiscal blindness.  This budget ignores the problems, kicks the can down the road again, and doesn't address the real causes of the debt and deficit.

What we need is another WPA / CCC which brought the 1928 Hoover unemployment rate of 25% down to under 15% by 1937.
Unfortunately concern about the deficit led to reduced govt. spending which raised unemployment in 1938-39 but of course not back to Hoover levels.
GOP austerity policies today would have that same destimulating effect.
A CCC would reduce youth [particularly minority youth] unemployment.
Both liberals and conservative know these New Deal measures would work as they did in the 1930's. But conservatives do not want to stimulate the economy. They want the economy to remain weak for partisan advantage in 2014-2016.Employers want to use high unemployment to restrain wage demands. The rich want low paid servants.
Cutting unemployment benefits and SNAP benefits will provide added incentives for the unemployed to become servants for the rich.
There are many non-rich who are being hurt badly by conservative economic policies. They listen to Rush Limbaugh and other talk radio haters whose policies would only worsen the condition of these non-rich.
I fear what will happen when these non-rich understand who is really shafting them.
I think another patch [as FDR applied in the 1930's] would be much more desireable than other violent type "solutions".

The great scam of the Reagan era was to cut income tax rates and double payroll tax rates. The latter led to surpluses in the social security trust fund that were then used ("borrowed") to cover the increase in defence spending. Now the Republicans want to cut social security benefits to put off the time when general revenue has to repay the social security trust fund for that borrowed money. What this effectively means is that people of my generation (I am 54 and was 23 when the Social Security Amendments of 1983 were passed) have been paying double for the previous generation's benefits and will now see our benefits cut. Effectively, therefore, we saw an increase in our tax rates (because we lost more in payroll taxes than we gained from Reagan's income tax cuts) to pay for current expenditure while the wealthy saw their net taxes cut. That is the true generational theft being carried out. The Republicans are responsible for it. The Democrats, who still tout the 1983 deal as a success are complicit in it.
And not only that, retired people continues to pay premiums for Medicare after retirement..

Social Security and Medicare are not "entitlement programs"; this is a myth. They are insurance (life annuity and medical) contracts to which their beneficiaries have contributed during their entire working life. These contributions, not the government's general revenue, sustain the systems.
